content.description: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is characterized by pervasive instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and emotions, along with marked impulsivity. The pattern begins by early adulthood and is present in various contexts.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A pervasive pattern of instability of interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, and marked impulsivity, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by ≥5 of: (1) Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment; (2) A pattern of unstable and intense relationships alternating between extremes of idealization and devaluation; (3) Identity disturbance; (4) Impulsivity in at least two potentially self-damaging areas; (5) Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior; (6) Affective instability due to marked reactivity of mood; (7) Chronic feelings of emptiness; (8) Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty controlling anger; (9) Transient, stress-related paranoid ideation or severe dissociative symptoms.
content.prevalence: Estimated at 1.6%–5.9% in the general population; more common in clinical settings.
content.age_of_onset: Symptoms usually appear by adolescence or early adulthood.
content.prognosis: Symptom severity may decrease over time with treatment; functional improvement possible. Suicide risk is elevated, especially without treatment.

circuitry: Hyperreactive amygdala with reduced prefrontal regulation.
Altered fronto-limbic connectivity contributing to emotional dysregulation.
neurochemistry: Dysregulation in serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine systems.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Heritability estimated at ~40–60%; often linked to early trauma, neglect, or invalidating environments.

history_psychosocial: Early attachment patterns, trauma history, and relationship instability.
Patterns of mood reactivity, impulsivity, and self-harm.
medical_assessment: Assess for comorbid psychiatric disorders, substance use, and self-injury.
standardized_measures: Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 Personality Disorders (SCID-5-PD).
risk_stratification: Suicide risk, impulsive behaviors, aggression, self-harm.
differential_diagnosis: Bipolar II Disorder (episodic vs. pervasive mood instability)
evaluation.team_and_process: Multidisciplinary team including psychiatry, psychotherapy, and crisis intervention planning.

behavioral: Impulsive spending, sex, substance use, binge eating

severity_levels.mild: Interpersonal instability with some preserved functioning; occasional self-harm or impulsivity.
severity_levels.moderate: Frequent crises, repeated self-harm, unstable work/relationships.
severity_levels.severe: Chronic suicidality, severe functional impairment, frequent hospitalizations.

biological: Family history of mood or personality disorders

impact_on_life.school_work: Interrupted education, unstable work history due to conflicts and emotional crises.
impact_on_life.social: Intense, unstable relationships; frequent breakups; social withdrawal during crises.
impact_on_life.medical: High use of emergency services; injury from self-harm.
impact_on_life.emotional: Persistent instability, distress, and difficulty maintaining hope.

psychotherapy: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) — emotion regulation, distress tolerance, interpersonal effectiveness.
medications: No FDA-approved medications; targeted use for symptom clusters: SSRIs/SNRIs for mood/anxiety, low-dose atypical antipsychotics for impulsivity or transient psychosis, mood stabilizers for affective lability.
care_coordination: Collaborative care with primary care, psychiatry, and therapists

treatment_goals: Stabilize mood and improve emotional regulation.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Misattributing mood swings to bipolar disorder.
Underrecognition of personality patterns in youth.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling transient adolescent instability as BPD without persistence.
Confusing complex PTSD symptoms with BPD.
self_help_strategies: Use crisis lines or safety plans when suicidal thoughts arise.
Engage in grounding and mindfulness exercises.

adolescence: Emerging instability in relationships and self-image, self-harm behaviors.
adulthood: Persistent mood reactivity, chronic emptiness, impulsivity; possible symptom reduction with treatment.

real_life_examples: A 22-year-old with frequent breakups, cutting behavior, and intense mood swings enters DBT and reduces self-harm episodes.
A 35-year-old with chronic emptiness, impulsive spending, and intense anger engages in schema therapy, improving relationships and stability.
content.when_to_seek_help: Immediate help if suicidal or engaging in self-harm; seek therapy when emotional instability or relationship patterns cause distress or impairment.
